story.text: (Updates to early morning) By Caroline ValetkevitchNEW YORK Jan 3 (Reuters) - U.S. stocks shot up on Wednesday, pushing the Dow industrials to an intraday record high and the Nasdaq index up 1 percent, with shares of Wal-Mart Stores Inc.(WMT.N) jumping after a stronger-than-expected sales forecast. Stock in Home Depot Inc. (HD.N) also gained sharply after the resignation of its chairman and chief executive revived takeover talk, while lower oil prices helped the outlook for stocks. For details, see [ID:nN30286457] On the Nasdaq, shares of Google Inc. (GOOG.O) rose. Stifel Nicolaus said Google has replaced eBay Inc. (EBAY.O) on its select list. The Dow Jones industrial average .DJI was up 80.19 points, or 0.64 percent, at 12,543.34. The Standard & Poor's 500 Index .SPX was up 6.61 points, or 0.47 percent, at 1,424.91. The Nasdaq Composite Index .IXIC was up 24.13 points, or 1.00 percent, at 2,439.42. "You're getting an inflow of reinvestment funds at the beginning of the year and normally you do get some upward pressure on the market in the initial sessions," said Michael Metz, chief investment strategist at Oppenheimer & Co. in New York. Shares of Wal-Mart rose 3.4 percent to $47.76, while shares of Home Depot gained 3.5 percent to $41.55. Shares of Google increased 1.2 percent to $465.88. Crude oil slipped below $60 a barrel as mild weather in the U.S. Northeast lessened demand for fuel there. [ID:nSP161243]. (Additional reporting by Ellis Mnyandu)
